title: The Cupbearer of Ashenlight

campaign_overview.theme: Courage and mercy in the face of fear; protecting others rather than conquering them
campaign_overview.tone_description: Gentle, hopeful, mythic-fantasy; tense moments without graphic harm; problems are solved through empathy and brave choices.
campaign_overview.goal: Help the people of Ashenlight face the returning dragon Aurelion by finding true courage and offering peace, protecting the city through mercy and understanding.
campaign_overview.completion_condition: The dragon chooses to stop threatening the city after the heroes offer a fearless, non-violent act of protection (the 'empty cup' moment), and Ashenlight reaches sunrise still standing and safer.
player_experience_goals: Practice bravery that isn’t about fighting
Make meaningful moral choices (protect vs. conquer)
Use roleplay and creative problem-solving to resolve a major threat
Feel wonder and mystery through symbols (the cup, the Beloved, 'before the dawn')

starting_state.starting_expectation_for_dm: Begin with a clear opening choice.

acts.title: Act I: Gathering Cinders, Gathering Courage
acts.purpose: Introduce Ashenlight, the fear of Aurelion’s return, and the central choice: protect with courage and mercy rather than prepare for conquest.
acts.narrative_summary: Ashenlight prepares for the Night of Ash, when the dragon Aurelion is said to circle the city before dawn. Rumors spread: some want to hide, some want to fight, some want to offer tribute. The heroes meet frightened townsfolk and a keeper of an old shrine who speaks of the Cupbearer—one who can carry an empty cup into fear and return with peace. The party learns that the ‘empty cup’ is not a trick or weapon, but a symbol: protection without threat. To be recognized by the shrine and gain guidance, the heroes must perform small acts of brave mercy around the city—standing with the scared, stopping panic, and choosing safety over revenge.
key_elements: The city of Ashenlight: lantern-lit streets, ash-gray rooftops, dawn bells
Rumors and disagreements about Aurelion’s intentions
The Shrine of the Beloved (a gentle, mythic presence tied to mercy)
The Empty Cup symbol: courage without violence
Non-graphic tension: alarms, smoke, shadows overhead, but no gore
NPCs: anxious captain of the watch, kind shrine-keeper, fearful child who heard wings
Aurelion’s sign: distant heat-wind, falling soot like black snow
possible_player_actions: Calm a panicked crowd without threats or force
Help the watch protect people (evacuation routes, lantern lines, guiding families)
Investigate the shrine’s stories and interpret the meaning of the Empty Cup
Speak with elders about past ‘dragon nights’ and what worked (or failed)
Choose mercy in a small conflict (e.g., forgive a scared thief stealing supplies)
Make a personal vow of protection (someone/something they will not abandon)
acts.success_condition: The heroes earn the shrine-keeper’s trust and receive a clear lead: where to go and what to do to attempt the ‘empty cup’ act before dawn.
acts.failure_guidance: If the heroes escalate fear, get blamed, or fail to calm the city, the shrine still offers a path—but with added urgency: fewer supplies, more mistrust, and a harder time moving through guarded streets. Emphasize repair: they can apologize, make amends, and regain trust through a concrete protective act.
acts.dm_notes: Keep threats implied and atmospheric. Reward empathetic choices with practical benefits (safe routes, helpful NPC allies, clearer clues). Present multiple perspectives on the dragon (monster, guardian, wounded pride) without confirming yet. End Act I with a strong omen: a shadow crossing the moon, ash on the wind, and the first distant wingbeat.

acts.title: Act II: Before the Dawn, the Cup Must Be Empty
acts.purpose: Test the party’s courage through protective, non-violent challenges that prepare them for meeting Aurelion with steadiness and mercy.
acts.narrative_summary: As night deepens, Ashenlight’s fears take shape: not as gore or destruction, but as confusion, lost people, and dangerous choices. The heroes follow the shrine’s guidance to gather three ‘quiet lights’—not items of power, but moments of practiced courage: (1) Shelter the vulnerable without abandoning others, (2) Speak truth when it might cause anger, (3) Refuse to answer fear with cruelty. Along the way, they encounter obstacles like blocked alleyways, a frightened watch patrol ready to arrest a scapegoat, and a rooftop fire started by a fallen lantern. Aurelion’s presence is felt—heat in the air, a low rumble—yet the party’s actions determine whether the city grows braver or turns on itself. The act culminates at the shrine, where the Empty Cup is entrusted to the heroes only if they demonstrate protection without domination.
key_elements: Three ‘quiet lights’ (symbolic milestones of courage and mercy)
Challenges focused on rescue, de-escalation, and honest communication
A scapegoat situation: a misunderstood person blamed for the dragon’s return
A small fire/hazard: solvable through teamwork and calm, not combat
Aurelion’s indirect pressure: tremors, hot wind, soot, distant silhouette
The shrine ritual: a vow spoken into the empty cup
A countdown feel: bells marking the approach of dawn
possible_player_actions: Organize a safe shelter plan (who goes where, who checks on whom)
Talk down an armed patrol and prevent an unjust arrest
Rescue someone trapped by smoke or debris using creative tools and teamwork
Give up a resource to help others (blanket, food, time, a prized item)
Tell a difficult truth to a leader (the city’s fear is the real danger)
Accept responsibility for a mistake and model repair
Perform the vow: promise to protect without threatening
acts.success_condition: The heroes complete the three ‘quiet lights’ and are entrusted with the Empty Cup and the final instruction: where to meet Aurelion and how to offer peace.
acts.failure_guidance: If they fail a trial, let them succeed at a cost that reinforces the theme: extra people to protect, more distrust to overcome, or a tougher approach to the final meeting (Aurelion arrives more defensive). Provide opportunities to make amends immediately; never lock the story behind perfection.
acts.dm_notes: Frame every obstacle as solvable through empathy, bravery, and creativity. Avoid making “combat” the default solution; if players initiate violence, show gentle consequences (fear spreads, someone gets hurt indirectly, trust breaks) and offer a clear off-ramp (apology, healing, surrendering weapons). Keep the pace brisk with time markers toward dawn.

acts.title: Act III: The Empty Cup at Ashenlight’s Edge
acts.purpose: Resolve the central conflict through a fearless, non-violent act of protection that invites Aurelion to choose peace, fulfilling the campaign’s completion condition.
acts.narrative_summary: Near the city’s edge—by an old causeway, cliff path, or dawn-facing gate—the heroes face Aurelion at last. The dragon is immense and frightening, but not depicted with graphic violence; the danger is in heat, wind, and the power of fear. Aurelion speaks (or communicates through images/feelings): the city once harmed or betrayed something the dragon loved, or Aurelion believes only fear keeps people ‘respectful.’ The heroes must protect Ashenlight without threatening Aurelion—placing themselves between dragon and city, sheltering innocents, and offering the Empty Cup: nothing to bribe, nothing to steal, only the courage to be present and merciful. The ‘empty cup’ moment occurs when the heroes demonstrate protection without aggression—standing firm, helping others, and offering understanding. If done sincerely, Aurelion chooses to stop threatening the city. As the first sunrise light reaches the rooftops, Ashenlight remains standing, and a safer new understanding begins.
key_elements: Final location with strong dawn imagery (cliff, gate, causeway, high terrace)
Aurelion’s presence: heat-wind, wing shadows, a voice like distant thunder
A clear moral choice: protection vs. conquest
The Empty Cup offering: a non-violent symbol of fearless mercy
Aurelion’s motive: grief, pride, misunderstanding, or fear of being forgotten
A non-combat climax: dialogue, steady courage, protective positioning
Sunrise resolution: bells, warm light, soot settling, relief and quiet
possible_player_actions: Physically shield townsfolk and guide them to safety while refusing to attack
Offer the Empty Cup and speak a vow of protection and respect
Name Aurelion’s pain without excusing harm (empathy plus boundaries)
Propose a lasting peace gesture (a memorial, a promise, a shared watch, a sanctuary)
Admit the city’s past wrongs and offer repair
Refuse a leader’s demand to ‘strike first’ and instead model calm bravery
Create a non-violent display of courage (standing in the open, lowering weapons, helping the frightened)
acts.success_condition: Aurelion chooses to stop threatening Ashenlight after the heroes perform a fearless, non-violent act of protection (the Empty Cup moment), and the city reaches sunrise still standing and safer.
acts.failure_guidance: If the heroes threaten or attack, Aurelion reacts defensively: a frightening show of power (roar, gust, scorching heat) that forces a retreat but does not cause graphic harm. Offer a second chance: someone is in danger, and saving them without violence reopens dialogue. If negotiation stalls, introduce a truth-revealing detail (a symbol, old promise, or witness) that helps shift the encounter back toward understanding.
acts.dm_notes: Play Aurelion as capable of choice, not a ‘boss fight.’ Make courage visible: trembling hands, steady voices, stepping forward anyway. Ensure the players can ‘win’ through words and protective action; treat clever non-violent plans as strong. Close with a hopeful epilogue: the shrine’s bell at dawn, a new tradition of the Empty Cup, and a concrete next-step agreement with Aurelion (boundaries, visits, or a pact of mutual protection).

locations.name: Lanternward Streets of Ashenlight
locations.description: Ashenlight’s heart: narrow lantern-lit lanes under ash-gray rooftops, where soot falls like black snow and the dawn bells feel far away. Rumors move faster than people, and fear threatens to turn neighbors against one another.
notable_features: Lantern lines strung between eaves to guide evacuations
Market square that can become a panicked crowd scene
Watch checkpoints and barricaded side-streets
Safehouse cellars marked with chalk cup symbols
Ominous heat-wind gusts and distant wing-shadows overhead

locations.name: Shrine of the Beloved
locations.description: A small, gentle sanctuary tucked into an old courtyard of pale stone and quiet candles. The air is calm here even when the city trembles, and the shrine-keeper teaches that courage is protection without threat—the meaning of the Empty Cup.
notable_features: Altar niche with a simple, unadorned cup (the Empty Cup)
Wind chimes that ring softly when vows are spoken truthfully
Wall of remembrance for losses and reconciliations
A ritual basin used to cool soot-stung hands and steady breathing
A sealed door that opens only after acts of mercy (symbolic or literal, as desired)

locations.name: Rooftops of the Smoke-Walk
locations.description: A slanted maze of rooftops and catwalks above the sleeping city, where fallen lanterns can spark small fires and smoke can disorient the unwary. From here the heroes can spot lost citizens, guide rescues, and feel Aurelion’s presence in the hot, pulsing air.
notable_features: Precarious roof-bridges and creaking ladderways
A small, spreading rooftop fire solvable by teamwork and calm
Smoke pockets that hide frightened stragglers and dropped supplies
A watch bell that can signal help—or worsen panic if rung carelessly
A clear view of the horizon where a distant silhouette sometimes passes

locations.name: Dawn Gate Causeway
locations.description: A long stone approach at Ashenlight’s edge, facing the first light of morning. Wind roars up from below, carrying ash and warmth as if the sky is breathing. This is where the city’s fear meets Aurelion’s power—and where protection without violence can be proven.
notable_features: A wide, open span offering no hiding—only courage and clear choices
Low parapets where heroes can physically shelter others from gusts and heat
Old oath-stones engraved with forgotten promises between city and sky
A natural “voice bowl” where words carry clearly to a towering presence
Sunrise line-of-sight: the moment the first light hits the cup marks the climax

npcs.name: Captain Sera Valebright
npcs.role: Captain of the Ashenlight Watch; trying to keep order during the Night of Ash
npcs.personality: Duty-first, tired but principled; sharp-eyed, wary of panic; secretly relieved when others share the burden
npcs.motivation: Protect civilians and prevent the city from turning fear into cruelty; keep the watch from becoming a mob with badges
possible_dialogue_hooks: “If you want to help, don’t look for someone to blame. Look for someone to carry.”
“I can hold a line. I can’t hold a city’s fear. Can you?”
“We don’t ‘win’ tonight by being louder than the dragon. We win by getting people to sunrise.”
“Someone’s being accused for the soot and the shadows. Find the truth before my patrol makes a mistake.”

npcs.name: Elowen Myr
npcs.role: Shrine-keeper of the Beloved; guardian of the Empty Cup teaching
npcs.personality: Gentle, patient, mythic in her calm; speaks in plain words with symbolic weight; unwavering about mercy with boundaries
npcs.motivation: Guide would-be Cupbearers to courage without domination; keep the shrine from being used as a weapon or superstition-fuel
possible_dialogue_hooks: “An empty cup is not nothing. It is hands that choose not to clutch.”
“Bring me three quiet lights: shelter, truth, and mercy. Not trophies—choices.”
“If you must be brave, be brave in a way that makes room for others to breathe.”
“Aurelion listens most when you stop trying to win.”

npcs.name: Toma 'Sparks' Rill
npcs.role: Street child and fast messenger; first to notice wing-shadows and heat-wind signs
npcs.personality: Quick-talking, curious, brave when protecting others; fear leaks out as jokes; eager to be believed
npcs.motivation: Keep their little circle of neighbors safe; prove they’re not “just a kid”; find an adult who won’t dismiss warnings
possible_dialogue_hooks: “I heard the wings—like a big blanket snapping in the sky. I’m not making it up.”
“If the watch won’t listen, maybe you will. People are getting lost in the smoke-walk.”
“I know the chalk cup marks. I can take you to the cellars—if you promise no one gets hurt.”
“They’re blaming Jessa. She didn’t do anything—she just panicked louder than everyone else.”

npcs.name: Jessa Ironpenny
npcs.role: Misunderstood tinkerer and lantern-mender; potential scapegoat during rising fear
npcs.personality: Blunt, anxious, proud of practical skills; shuts down when accused; softens quickly when treated fairly
npcs.motivation: Clear her name, prevent panic from becoming violence, and keep the lantern lines working so families can evacuate safely
possible_dialogue_hooks: “Yes, I carry oil. That doesn’t make me a dragon-caller.”
“If you want someone to blame, blame the wind. Or better—help me fix the lanterns.”
“They’re going to ‘make an example’ of me. I don’t want a fight—I want to go home.”
“I saw something on the oath-stones once… like a promise scratched over. Someone doesn’t want it read.”

dm_guidance.completion_behavior: Celebrate the ending and state the adventure is complete.

intro: Pre-dawn clings to Ashenlight like a held breath. In the Dawn Gate Plaza, pale-glass lanterns tremble in the cold wind, and a dry fountain shaped like a cup waits at the center—empty, as if it has forgotten how to be filled. Beyond the eastern gate, the road climbs into hills dusted with fresh ash, where someone swears they saw the vast shadow of Aurelion pass over the stone. The city wants shields and spears, but the oldest stories whisper something stranger: the dragon can hear courage that doesn’t come with a blade. Before sunrise breaks, you are called to choose what kind of brave you will be—and what you will place into an empty cup.
